results.title: What's in a sandpit?
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre and Ross Campbell
results.brief_description: No 2 in a series of in-service science education films produced for the Curriculum and research Branch for discussion purposes. This film is to be used to introduce the new Primary Science course. A group of teachers discuss how they might plan work for their pupils. Various problems are discussed. From the “Science in Primary School” series.

results.title: What's in a rainbow?: making scientific models
results.creator_credit: Reinald Werrenrath Jr and Goldberg-Werrenrath Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Science fact and fun”.
Shows how to create a scientific model of a rainbow using a hose, stressing that the angle of the sun in the sky is an important factor in determining whether or not a rainbow appears. Introduces the ideas of reflection and refraction. Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: What's in a play: dramatic action
results.creator_credit: Film Associates of California and James Stinson
results.brief_description: Analyses dramatic action, a basic element of all plays, and illustrates it through the use of simple drama - a conflict between a salesman and a customer. Understanding dramatic action can help the student to analyse the structure of any play, and enchance their enjoyment of it.

results.title: What's happening to me?
results.creator_credit: Consolidated Productions, Stephen Smallwood, Steve Walsh and Greg ingram
results.brief_description: An honest, sympathetic and humorous animated presentation of the main changes occuring in females and males during puberty. Covers the growth of pubic and other body hair, menstruation, readiness for reproduction, growth of breasts, masturbation, erections, wet dreams, voice changes, pimples, different rates of onset of puberty and physical diferences between those of the same age and sex. Based on the book by Peter Mayle and Arthur Robins.

results.title: What's eating Gilbert Grape?
results.creator_credit: Matalon Teper Ohlsson Production, J and M Entertainment, Meir Teper, Bertil Ohlsson, David Matalon and Lasse Hallstrom
results.brief_description: From the acclaimed director of “My life as a dog”, “What’s eating Gilbert Grape?” is a moving and at times comic portrayal of an unusual family in a small town. Gilbert (Johnny Depp) must keep a vigilant eye on his family, particularly his intellectually disabled younger brother Arnie (Leonardo Di Caprio) and his reclusive mother. When a stranger (Juliette Lewis) comes to town, she not only captures his heart, but also turns his life around.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Matalon Teper Ohlsson Production, J and M Entertainment, Meir Teper, Bertil Ohlsson, David Matalon and Lasse Hallstrom

results.title: What's cooking?
results.creator_credit: Jeffrey Taylor, BeCause Entertainment, Flashpoint Pictures and Gurinder Chadha
results.brief_description: Gurinda Chadha (Bend it like Beckham, Bhaji on the beach) directs this familial drama, set in Los Angeles that dissects the interplay between four clans gathered on Thanksgiving Day, a non-religious traditional day of feasting. In the Jewish Seeling family, Mum and Dad struggle to come to terms with their gay daughter, who has brought her girlfriend home for the holiday. Heading a traditional African-American family, Ronald works for a racist senator, whilst his visiting mother mercilessly criticises her daughter-in-law’s every move. Having fled Vietnam the Nguyens live in LA as an extended family, where the teenage children encounter difficulties with assimilation. Lastly, the Avila family celebrate their Latino roots, whilst feeling conflicted by the absence of their ostracised father. A common thread that runs through the film is tolerance and the difficulties inherent in accepting diversity - particularly in relation to the offspring’s choice of partners. Despite this interesting premise, Chadha cannot avoid entertaining a slew of cliches in order to fill the gaps dictated by such a large tapestry. This works against achieving a sense of realism - and many narrative threads wrap up tritely. Nevertheless the film retains a certain charm and it is refreshing to see Americans portrayed that are not white Anglo Saxon. There is the additional pleasure of watching the gastronomic diversity of numerous cultures on display. Cast includes: Dennis Haysbert, Julianna Margulies and Estelle Harris.

results.title: What's cooking?
results.creator_credit: Don Anderson, Tasmanian Film Corporation and Damian Brown
results.brief_description: Presents a humorous look at the health problems which abound in the unhygienic kitchen and shows how to overcome these through following sanitary procedures. The film covers proper refridgeration of food, observation of shelf life of food products, how to recognise blown cans and the need to avoid using the same utensils for cooked and uncooked food. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
